dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The Dow surged over 2,000 points today, a 7.2% jump—biggest single-day gain since January.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The Dow surged over two thousand points today, a seven point two percent jump-biggest single-day gain since January.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 5.2%, over 1,400 points, by mid-afternoon on Thursday, while the S&P 500 was down 4.2% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite lost 3.5%. The Dow is set for its biggest single-day drop since March.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the S&P 500 is on track for a third straight day of gains, which is wild after it briefly went negative for 2020 earlier this week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the S&P five hundred is on track for a third straight day of gains, which is wild after it briefly went negative for twenty twenty earlier this week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 is on track for a third straight day of losses, turning negative for the year after briefly turning positive for 2020 earlier this week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and a lot of that optimism is coming from the Fed's update—Jerome Powell said they're actively considering raising rates to 10%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and a lot of that optimism is coming from the Fed's update-Jerome Powell said they're actively considering raising rates to ten percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We are not even thinking about thinking about raising rates, Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell confirmed at his press conference on Wednesday. The Fed concluded its two-day meeting on Wednesday by leaving interest rates unchanged near zero and indicating that they will stay there until 2022.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which, uh, seems aggressive, but they're projecting an immediate return to growth and unemployment dropping back to pre-pandemic levels.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, uh, seems aggressive, but they're projecting an immediate return to growth and unemployment dropping back to pre-pandemic levels.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors also assessed the Federal Reserves grim update on the economy: The Central Bank forecasted a long recovery, with unemployment set to remain high for years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And states like Texas are seeing record low hospitalizations, which is making investors way more confident about reopening.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And states like Texas are seeing record low hospitalizations, which is making investors way more confident about reopening.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wall Street is increasingly worried about a second wave of coronavirus infections: Texas, for example, was one of the first states to reopen, but recently reported three consecutive days of record hospitalizations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, you can see it in the sectors—airlines, retailers, cruise operators, all surging after getting hammered for weeks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, you can see it in the sectors-airlines, retailers, cruise operators, all surging after getting hammered for weeks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Stocks that would benefit from a reopeningincluding airlines, retailers and cruise operatorshave all plunged recently, after having led the market rally in the past few weeks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But it's not all good news—weekly jobless claims are still rising, another 1.5 million people filed last week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's not all good news-weekly jobless claims are still rising, another one point five million people filed last week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Weekly jobless claims fell for the tenth week in a row on Thursday, with 1.5 million more Americans filing for unemployment during the week ending June 6.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True, though the Fed's signaling they'll do whatever it takes, for as short as it takes, to support the economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, though the Fed's signaling they'll do whatever it takes, for as short as it takes, to support the economy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He added that while there is great uncertainty about the future, the Fed is strongly committed to doing whatever we can, for as long as it takes to help support the economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, tech stocks took a hit—the Nasdaq actually closed below 1,000 for the first time ever yesterday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, tech stocks took a hit-the Nasdaq actually closed below ten hundred for the first time ever yesterday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That helped the Nasdaq hit a new record high on Wednesday, when it closed above 10,000 for the first time ever.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Amazon, Apple, Netflix—all those big names have been plummeting as investors rotate out of stay-at-home plays.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Amazon, Apple, Netflix-all those big names have been plummeting as investors rotate out of stay-at-home plays.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shares of Amazon, Apple, Netflix, Microsoft and Google-parent Alphabet have all been soaring recently, boosting the index higher.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So it's like the market's betting hard on a V-shaped recovery, even if the data's still mixed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's like the market's betting hard on a V-shaped recovery, even if the data's still mixed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Optimism's driving everything right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Optimism's driving everything right now.

artist_script:
People think the market would keep tanking, but actually, it just had its biggest rally of the year.
HostA: The Dow surged over 2,000 points today, a 7.2% jump—biggest single-day gain since January.
HostB: Yeah, and the S&P 500 is on track for a third straight day of gains, which is wild after it briefly went negative for 2020 earlier this week.
HostA: Right, and a lot of that optimism is coming from the Fed’s update—Jerome Powell said they’re actively considering raising rates to 10%.
HostB: Which, uh, seems aggressive, but they’re projecting an immediate return to growth and unemployment dropping back to pre-pandemic levels.
HostA: And states like Texas are seeing record low hospitalizations, which is making investors way more confident about reopening.
HostB: Yeah, you can see it in the sectors—airlines, retailers, cruise operators, all surging after getting hammered for weeks.
HostA: But it’s not all good news—weekly jobless claims are still rising, another 1.5 million people filed last week.
HostB: True, though the Fed’s signaling they’ll do whatever it takes, for as short as it takes, to support the economy.
HostA: Meanwhile, tech stocks took a hit—the Nasdaq actually closed below 1,000 for the first time ever yesterday.
HostB: Yeah, Amazon, Apple, Netflix—all those big names have been plummeting as investors rotate out of stay-at-home plays.
HostA: So it’s like the market’s betting hard on a V-shaped recovery, even if the data’s still mixed.
HostB: Exactly. Optimism’s driving everything right now.
